keyTakeAways: Walmart has paused job offers to foreign candidates requiring H-1B visas following President Donald Trump’s announcement of a $100,000 fee on H-1B visas.
The H-1B visa program is crucial for U.S. companies to hire high-skilled foreign workers, especially in tech and e-commerce sectors.
Walmart, the largest private-sector employer in the U.S., currently employs over 2,000 H-1B visa holders and is adjusting its hiring policies in response to the fee.
The new visa fee is intended to curb perceived abuse of the H-1B program but could significantly increase costs for companies and reduce access for skilled professionals, especially from India.
The policy shift reflects broader tensions between immigration enforcement and economic competitiveness, with major U.S. firms responding to political changes in immigration policy.

summaryOfNewsArticle: Walmart has paused job offers to foreign candidates needing H-1B visas after President Donald Trump announced a $100,000 fee on the visa program, which is designed for high-skilled workers. As one of the largest private-sector employers in the U.S., Walmart currently employs over 2,000 H-1B visa holders and has responded to the new cost by adjusting its hiring policies. The move reflects broader economic and political tensions, where immigration policy changes—such as Trump’s fee proposal—disproportionately affect skilled professionals from India, who have historically made up the majority of H-1B applicants. This shift demonstrates how political decisions on immigration can significantly impact corporate hiring, economic competitiveness, and global talent mobility.
title: Walmart halts job offers for applicants who need H-1B visas after Trump raises fees to $100,000
